citation.article-title: Gulbenkiania indica sp. nov., isolated from a sulfur spring
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Gulbenkiania indica sp. nov.
Gulbenkiania indica (in′di.ca. L. fem. adj. indica of India, the geographical origin of the type strain).
Cells are rods, 1.1 μm wide by 2.3 μm long.
Cells usually occur singly, and are motile by means of a single polar flagellum.
Colonies on nutrient agar plates are smooth, mucoid, round and cream-coloured.
Positive for catalase, oxidase and growth on MacConkey agar medium.

Negative for methyl red test, Voges–Proskauer reaction, indole production, urease, H2S production, citrate utilization, anaerobic growth in the presence of nitrate, gelatin liquefaction and starch hydrolysis.

Negative for assimilation of d-mannose, d-glucose, d-mannitol, d-xylose, maltose, lactose, sucrose, raffinose, d-rhamnose, d-arabinose, d-ribose, d-fructose, d-sorbose, trehalose, sodium succinate, sodium malate, sodium fumarate, l-glutamic acid, l-leucine, l-glycine, l-alanine, l-proline, l-aspartic acid, l-tryptophan, l-phenylalanine, l-methionine, l-serine, l-valine, l-isoleucine, l-histidine and l-asparagine.
Positive for assimilation of sodium acetate, inositol, 4-aminobutyric acid, l-tyrosine, l-threonine, l-lysine and l-cysteine.
The major fatty acids are C16 : 1ω7c, C16 : 0, C18 : 1ω7c, C12 : 0, C12 : 0 3-OH and C10 : 0 3-OH.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 63.0 mol%.
Phylogenetically, this bacterium belongs to the family Neisseriaceae.
The type strain, HT27T (=DSM 17901T =JCM 15969T), was isolated from a sulfur spring in Orissa, India.
